Trial_Design.evidence: The study is a secondary analysis of the Therapeutic Hypothermia after Pediatric Cardiac Arrest In-Hospital Trial.

Participants.evidence: Fifty-six children who received open-chest CPR for in-hospital cardiac arrest were included.

Intervention.evidence: Fifty-six children who received open-chest CPR for in-hospital cardiac arrest were included.

Objective.evidence: Our objective was to describe neurobehavioral outcomes one year post-arrest among children who received open-chest CPR during in-hospital cardiac arrest; and explore factors associated with one-year survival and survival with good neurobehavioral outcome.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Neurobehavioral status was assessed using the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Second Edition (VABS-II) at pre-arrest baseline and 12-months post-arrest.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifty-six children who received open-chest CPR for in-hospital cardiac arrest were included.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of 56 children receiving open-chest CPR, 49 (88%) were post-cardiac surgery and 43 (77%) were <1 year old.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Thirty-three (59%) survived to 12 months, 22 (41%) survived to 12 months with VABS-II decreased by ≤15 points from baseline, and of those with baseline VABS-II ≥70, 23 (51%) survived to 12 months with VABS-II ≥70.
